    The Medicinal Chemistry of Therapeutic Oligonucleotides

    • W. Brad Wan
      •  and 
    • Punit P. Seth*
    View Author Information
    Department of Medicinal Chemistry, Ionis Pharmaceuticals, 2855 Gazelle Court, Carlsbad, California 92010, United States
    *Phone: 760-603-2587. Fax: 760-603-3891. E-mail: [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2016, 59, 21, 9645–9667
    Publication Date (Web):July 19, 2016

    Publication History

    • Received11 April 2016
    • Published online29 July 2016
    • Published inissue 10 November 2016
    https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jmedchem.6b00551
    Copyright © 2016 American Chemical Society

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Oligonucleotide-based therapeutics have made rapid progress in the clinic for treatment of a variety of disease indications. Unmodified oligonucleotides are polyanionic macromolecules with poor drug-like properties. Over the past two decades, medicinal chemists have identified a number of chemical modification and conjugation strategies which can improve the nuclease stability, RNA-binding affinity, and pharmacokinetic properties of oligonucleotides for therapeutic applications. In this perspective, we present a summary of the most commonly used nucleobase, sugar and backbone modification, and conjugation strategies used in oligonucleotide medicinal chemistry.

    1 Introduction and Background

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) are short (12–24-mers) chemically modified oligonucleotides which bind to their cognate mRNA in cells by Watson–Crick base-pairing (Figure 1) and modulate its function to produce a pharmacological effect.(1) The requirement for Watson–Crick base-pairing with the targeted RNA essentially distinguishes ASOs from other oligonucleotide therapeutic modalities such as aptamers, immunomodulatory oligonucleotides, and mRNA therapeutics. Oligonucleotide aptamers have defined three-dimensional structures which interact with their biological targets (typically proteins).(2) Immunomodulatory oligonucleotides interact with proteins of the immune system via discrete motifs (such as CpG oligonucleotides).(3) mRNA therapeutics aim to deliver a chemically modified RNA to cells where it can be translated to a functional protein.(4) For the purpose of this chapter, we will focus predominantly on examples derived from the antisense literature. However, the general principles of using chemical modifications to modulate the drug-like properties of ASOs are also applicable to other classes of oligonucleotide-based therapeutics.
    Upon binding to mRNA, therapeutic oligonucleotides can elicit a biological response via a number of distinct antisense mechanisms. These can be broadly classified as mechanisms which promote degradation of the targeted mRNA or which are occupancy based and do not promote degradation of RNA.(1) Single-stranded DNA oligonucleotides activate the RNaseH antisense mechanism.(5) RNase H1 is a ubiquitously expressed enzyme which selectively cleaves the RNA strand of a RNA/DNA heteroduplex.(6) Double- or single-stranded RNA oligonucleotides function via the RISC pathway where the enzyme Argonaute2 cleaves the mRNA strand of the RNA/RNA duplex.(7) In contrast, oligonucleotides of various chemical compositions can bind mRNA at specific locations such as close to exon–intron junctions or translation initiation sites and modulate RNA splicing or arrest translation without causing RNA degradation.(8, 9) In addition, oligonucleotides can also bind to and antagonize endogenous micro RNAs which are important regulators of gene expression.(10-12) Indeed, oligonucleotides which function via all of the above (and additional) antisense mechanisms have progressed in the clinic for the treatment of a wide variety of disease indications.
    Despite the enormous potential of the antisense approach, it took almost two decades for the concept to be firmly established in the clinic. Key reasons which led to success included the identification of tissues which accumulate ASOs and are sensitive to antisense effects, a more sophisticated understanding of the pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic properties of ASOs in animal models, a steady progress in our understanding of the fundamental biology of antisense mechanisms, and advancement of oligonucleotide medicinal chemistry and production strategies which allowed for a large number of ASOs with improved drug-like properties to be synthesized and screened for biological activity.(13)
    Early work established that unmodified nucleic acids have limited stability in biological media and undergo rapid nuclease mediated degradation. They also have poor pharmacokinetic properties, causing them to be filtered by the glomerulus and excreted in the urine rapidly after administration to an animal.(14, 15) From a medicinal chemistry perspective, key attributes for enhancing the drug-like properties of oligonucleotides include enhancing binding affinity for the target RNA, enhancing stability against nuclease mediated metabolism, improving pharmacokinetic properties in animals, and maintaining or conferring the ability to elicit a functional antisense response. In the following sections, we will focus on medicinal chemistry strategies commonly used to improve the drug-like properties of oligonucleotides for therapeutic applications.

    2 Sites of Modification on an Oligonucleotide

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    There are several sites on an oligonucleotide which are amenable for chemical modification without interfering with the base-pairing ability of the ASO.(16) Even when considering a minimal dinucleotide subunit, at least 25 positions may be substituted (Figure 2). Modifications to the nucleobases can enhance or modulate base-pairing specificity. Modifications to the phosphodiester backbone can modulate nuclease stability and pharmacokinetic properties. Modifications to the furanose sugar moiety can enhance binding affinity and modulate nuclease stability and/or interactions with cellular proteins which can enhance or decrease ASO activity. Conjugation of lipophilic or cell targeting moieties can modulate protein binding and tissue targeting properties.

    3 Nucleobase Modifications

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Modification to the nucleobase can affect the ability of an ASO to interact with its target mRNA by Watson–Crick base-pairing. Despite several decades of research into nucleobase modifications, very few have found successful application within antisense medicinal chemistry. Modifications to the nucleobase impacts base-pairing properties of the ASO, which can reduce binding affinity and/or specificity for the targeted mRNA. Another impediment is the concern that metabolism of modified ASOs could generate nucleoside metabolites which can compete with natural nucleotide pools for incorporation into genomic material and/or interfere with the functioning of polymerases. There is, however, one naturally occurring nucleobase modification which is used extensively in nucleic acid medicinal chemistry to improve duplex stability and nuclease resistance as well as mitigate the immunostimulatory properties of ASOs. This modification is the C-5 methyl substitution on pyrimidine nucleobases, which in turn inspired the design of new classes of heterocycle modifications for use in nucleic acid medicinal chemistry (Figure 3).

    3.1 5-Methyl Pyrimidines

    The 5-methyl group on pyrimidine nucleobases (thymine and 5-methyl cytosine) enhances the thermal stability of oligonucleotide duplexes by ∼0.5 °C per modification. The increase stems from the ability of the methyl group to stack between the planar nucleobases in the major groove. Introduction of the 5-methyl group on cytosine reduces the immunostimulatory profile of certain DNA oligonucleotides and also enhances nuclease stability. However, 5-methyl substitution of the pyrimidine nucleobases typically reduces activity of siRNA and is generally not as useful for this antisense mechanism. Substitution with larger alkyl groups such as 5-ethyl reduces affinity.(17) Substitution with a halogen at the C-5 position improves affinity, but these substituents have lower chemical stability and are thus less useful.

    3.2 5-Substituted Pyrimidine Analogues

    The success of 5-methyl substitution resulted in a number of analogues being prepared and evaluated for improving ASO affinity for complementary RNA (Figure 3). Matteucci introduced a propynyl group at the C-5 position of pyrimidine nucleobases which further improved duplex stability relative to C-5 methyl substitution.(18, 19) The improved duplex stabilizing property was attributed to efficient stacking of the acetylinic group between the planar nucleobases in the major groove. Further expansion of this concept resulted in the identification of C-5 thiazole pyrimdines, which also improved duplex thermal stability.(20, 21) The cytosine nucleobase can also be replaced with a phenoxazine ring which retains the ability to form Watson–Crick base-pairing but extends the planar surface area for improved stacking.(22) Further modification of the phenoxazine nucleobase by addition of an aminopropyloxy side chain provided unparalleled increases in duplex thermal stability. These analogues were termed G-clamps because of their ability to form more than three hydrogen bonds with guanosine.(23, 24) More recently, Nielsen(25, 26) and Hrdlicka(27-30) have introduced a variety of C5 modified pyrimidine nucleobases which can provide dramatic increases in binding affinity for complementary nucleic acids.

    3.3 2-Thio-thymine

    Ostergaard et al. recently showed that site-specific incorporation of 2-thio dT can modulate the allele selectivity of ASOs by targeting single nucleotide polymorphisms for the treatment of Huntington’s disease.(31) Introduction of 2-thio dT at specific locations within the gap region affects the cleavage pattern of human RNase H(32) for matched and mismatched RNA/ASO duplexes, corresponding to the duplexes formed between the ASO and the mutant and wild-type huntingtin transcripts.(33) A structural model of the modified duplexes suggested that the 2-thio moiety can cause a steric clash with key amino acid side chains adjacent to the catalytic site in RNase H1. Interestingly, placing a large triazole-phenyl substituent at the C5-position had no effect on RNase H activity as this substituent projects into the major groove away from the catalytic site.(33)

    3.4 Purine Modifications

    The diaminopurine base (Figure 3) can donate a third hydrogen bond to thymine and is therefore analogous to a GC base pair.(34, 35) This modification enhances duplex thermal stability by ∼1.5 °C per incorporation(36) but is susceptible to depurination under acidic conditions used for removal of the dimethoxytrityl group during oligonucleotide synthesis, which limits its practical utility. The N2-imidazolylpropyl(37) and N2-aminopropyl(38) analogues of guanine (Figure 3) enhanced duplex thermal stability (ΔTm + 1 to +3.3 °C) as the cationic groups make contacts with the phosphate backbone in the major groove.
    Heterocyclic modifications have also been reported in deaza series where a nitrogen atom was replaced with a carbon atom (Figure 3). These modifications did not improve affinity except when combined with the propynyl substitution on 2-amino-7-deaza-adenosine.(39) Increased RNA binding affinity was also observed by incorporating 7-propynyl-7-deazadeoxy adenosine or 7-propynyl-7-deazadeoxyguanosine,(40) but synthetic challenges made it difficult to prepare sufficient quantities for evaluation in animals.

    4 Backbone Modifications

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The phosphodiester backbone in DNA and RNA is rapidly hydrolyzed by nucleases in biological media, thus limiting its utility for therapeutic applications. Significant effort has been expended to identify alternate backbones which maintain or enhance affinity for RNA, enhance stability toward nucleases, do not impair the ability of the ASO to elicit a functional response, and are chemically stable to reagents commonly used for automated oligonucleotide synthesis.
    Some of the most common backbone modifications replace one of the nonbridging oxygen atoms of the PO linkage with sulfur, carbon, nitrogen, or boron (Figure 4). While conceptually straightforward, these changes can have profound consequences on the physicochemical and biological properties of the resulting oligonucleotides. For example, replacing the nonbridging oxygen atom with sulfur provides the phosphorothioate linkage which is negatively charged, enhances nuclease stability, and exhibits chemical stability similar to the PO linkage.(41)
    Replacing the oxygen with a carbon results in the alkylphosphonate linkage, which is charge-neutral, reduces affinity for RNA and is unstable in basic conditions used to deprotect the oligonucleotide after synthesis.(42) In contrast, replacing the oxygen with a nitrogen provides the phosphoramidate linkage which is also charge neutral, reduces affinity for RNA, and is unstable under the acidic conditions used for removal of the dimethoxytrityl protecting group during automated oligonucleotide synthesis.(43) Replacing the anionic oxygen atom with an alkoxy group provides the phosphotriester linkage which is also neutral and labile under basic conditions used to deprotect oligonucleotides after synthesis. Recently, Dowdy et al. have reported the synthesis of siRNA modified with bioreversible phosphotriester linkages which are metabolized to release the parent siRNA in the cytosol.(44) Boranophosphonate is another interesting backbone modification which has been used sparingly to enhance the nuclease stability of RNaseH ASOs(45) and siRNA.(46)
    Several other backbone modifications which replace one of the bridging oxygen atoms of the PO linkage with carbon (3′-methylene phosphonates)(47) or nitrogen (N3′-phosphoramidates)(48) have been described (Figure 5). In addition, backbone modifications where the PO linkage is completely replaced with amide, formacetal/thioformacetal, aminooxy, and triazole moieties have been reported (Figure 6).(13)

    4.1 Phosphorothioate (PS)

    The phosphorothioate (PS) linkage represents one of the most widely used modifications in oligonucleotide medicinal chemistry.(49) In general, the PS linkage has similar chemical properties as the PO linkage and can be synthesized using conditions similar to those used for the preparation of PO oligonucleotides. The PS modification greatly enhances the metabolic stability of oligonucleotides but reduces affinity for complementary nucleic acids (∼−0.5 °C per incorporation).(50) The PS modification also confers a substantial pharmacokinetic benefit by increasing the binding to plasma proteins which prevents rapid renal excretion and facilitates binding to cell surface proteins such as stabilins, which facilitate ASO uptake into cells and tissues.(51) Conversely, the PS modification can enhance ASO binding to immune receptors, resulting in nonspecific pro-inflammatory toxicities.(52)
    A peculiar feature of the PS modifications is that the negative charge resides exclusively on the sulfur atom which introduces chirality at phosphorus.(49) As a consequence, a uniformly PS modified 20-mer ASO will be comprised of a mixture of 219 stereoisomers. Pioneering work by Stec showed that the Rp isomer has a higher Tm but is more susceptible to nuclease mediated degradation.(53) In contrast, the Sp isomer is slightly more destabilizing but significantly more stable to nucleases. Recent improvements in the synthetic methodology developed by Wada enabled the synthesis and study of stereopure PS ASOs.(54-57) Surprisingly, controlling chirality at each PS linkage in the gap region of RNase H ASOs provided no discernible benefits in cells or in animal experiments relative to the stereorandom mixture.(58)

    4.2 Methylphosphonate

    The methylphosphonate modification in which one of the nonbridging oxygen atoms is replaced by a methyl group represents one of the earliest reported neutral backbone modifications (Figure 4).(59) The ability to prepare this modification using standard solid phase synthesis protocols made it possible to rigorously evaluate the biophysical and biochemical properties of methylphosphonate modified oligonucleotides.(60) The methylphosphonate linkage is stable toward nuclease mediated degradation but is prone to cleavage under the basic conditions required to deprotect oligonucleotides after solid-phase synthesis.(42) High methylphosphonate content in an oligomer reduces aqueous solubility and also leads to loss in affinity toward complementary RNA. Like the PS linkage, the methylphosphonate linkage is also chiral and the Rp isomer exhibits higher binding affinity than the Sp isomer.(61) Overall, these shortcomings have made this modification less desirable and the value of methylphosphonates to oligonucleotide drug applications appear to be limited.

    4.3 N3′–P5′ Phosphoramidates and Thiophosphoroamidates

    Replacing the 3′-oxygen atom of the PO linkage with a nitrogen atom provides the N3′-phosphoramidate modification (Figure 5). N3′-Phosphoramidate linked oligonucleotides exhibited high affinity toward complementary RNA (ΔTm ∼ 2.5 °C per modification) and high nuclease resistance.(62, 63) Although limited biological evaluation of ASOs containing the N3′-phosphoramidate modification showed some promise,(64, 65) this modification was found to have low affinity to intra- and extracellular proteins and decreased acid stability relative to phosphodiester counterparts.
    To address these issues, thiophosphoramidate linkages were prepared and found to be more acid stable when incorporated into oligonucleotides.(66) A N3′–P5′ thiophosphoramidate ASO (GRN163)(67) showed good activity for telomerase inhibition and therapeutic utility in multiple myeloma and lymphoma models.(68) Thiophosphoroamidate ASOs additionally modified with various lipid groups have shown significant promise as antitelomerase agents,(69) thus making this an intriguing backbone modification for use in oligonucleotide medicinal chemistry.

    4.4 Amides

    The phosphodiester linkage in nucleic acids can be completely replaced with an amide linkage (Figure 6). De Mesmaeker et al. prepared nucleoside dimers linked by an amide linkage and incorporated them into oligonucleotides using phosphoramidite chemistry.(70) The modified oligonucleotides showed a modest increase in duplex thermal stability versus complementary RNA (ΔTm of 0.5 °C per modification) but not versus DNA.(71) The amide bond is thought to assume a trans conformation which preorganizes the sugar into the C3′-endo conformation and enhances affinity for complementary RNA. Introducing a 2′-O-methyl group further enhanced duplex stability (ΔTm of 2–3 °C per dimer). Substitution with a methyl group in the S configuration at the 5′-position of amide linked dimers resulted in an enhancement in Tm of almost 4 °C per incorporation.(72) Recently, Rozners et al. has demonstrated the utility of the amide linkage for stabilizing siRNA from nuclease mediated degradation.(73)

    4.5 Methylene(methylimino) (MMI)

    The PO linkage can also be replaced with other nitrogen containing achiral four atom linkages.(74) Sanghvi et al. showed that the methylene(methylimino) (MMI) linkage can be an effective replacement for the PO linkage (Figure 6).(75) Like the amide linkage, the thermal stability of MMI linked dimers can be further enhanced by incorporating a fluorine atom or a methoxy group at the 2′-position (ΔTm 3.2 to 3.7 °C per dimer modification).(76) The MMI linkage is completely resistant to nucleases but does not support RNase H activity near the site of incorporation. ASOs with more than 50% MMI content display reduced aqueous solubility and are susceptible to faster renal clearance, resulting in lower tissues levels of drug as a consequence of decreased plasma protein binding.

    4.6 Formacetal and Thioformacetal

    The formacetal backbone substitution replaces the PO linkage with a methylene unit. A related modification is the thioformacetal (Figure 6), which replaces the 3′-side oxygen atom with sulfur.(77) The formacetal linkage reduces duplex thermal stability, but the thioformacetal linkage increased affinity slightly.(78) The enhanced duplex stability was attributed to the thioformacetal adopting the C3′-endo sugar pucker which enhances affinity for RNA.(79) In one study, a systematic positional SAR led to the selection of a modified aptamer with four formacetal groups that increased anticoagulant effect combined with extended half-life in monkeys when compared to the parent aptamer.(80)

    4.7 Morpholino Phosphorodiamidate

    Phosphorodiamidate morpholinos (PMOs, Figure 7) are a class of oligonucleotide analogues where the ribofuranose ring is replaced with a morpholino ring and the phosphodiester backbone is replaced with a phosphorodiamidate linkage.(81) PMOs are neutral and have similar affinity as DNA:DNA duplexes and are extremely resistant to nucleases. However, they do not support RNase H activity and are used predominantly for translation arrest or for splice switching applications.(82, 83) Despite their neutral character, PMOs traverse cell membranes poorly and show modest activity in animal models unless conjugated to cationic peptides.(84) PMOs designed to induce exon skipping are being evaluated in late stage clinical trials for the treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.(85)

    4.8 Peptide Nucleic Acid (PNA)

    Peptide nucleic acids (Figure 7) are a class of oligonucleotide analogues where the sugar phosphate backbone is replaced with a peptide scaffold yet maintain the ability to Watson–Crick base pair with complementary nucleic acids.(86) PNAs are extremely resistant to degradation by nucleases and proteases and are very stabilizing when paired with RNA and DNA.(87, 88) PNAs do not support RNase H activity but have been used in translation inhibition(89, 90) and splice modulation antisense mechanisms.(83, 91) PNAs do not cross cell membranes readily despite their neutral character and need special methods to deliver them to cells. PNA oligonucleotides also have very poor aqueous solubility and are very poorly protein bound. Conjugation of PNAs with short peptides(92, 93) or charged amino acids(94) in the PNA backbone can increase solubility and improve tissue distribution.(95)

    5 Furanose Sugar Modifications

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The furanose ring of natural nucleic acids has been a site of extensive modification within antisense medicinal chemistry. Modification of the sugar moiety has the ability to modulate ASO RNA-binding affinity, nuclease stability, and functional activity. Unlike base modifications which can only be applied in the context of ASO sequence, sugar modifications can be applied at any site within an ASO. Furthermore, sugar modifications can also be combined in a modular manner with nucleobase and backbone modifications to create a large universe of nucleic acid analogues.
    Small structural changes to the sugar moiety can have profound consequences on the biophysical and biological properties of oligonucleotides. This concept is perhaps best illustrated by comparing DNA and RNA, which only differ by a hydroxyl group at the 2′-position. Yet, this simple modification changes the inherent biophysical and biochemical properties of these nucleic acid polymers along with their role in biology.

    5.1 2′-Modified RNA

    The furanose sugar in DNA and RNA is replete with electronic effects because of the presence of electron withdrawing oxygen atoms at on every carbon (except the 2′-position in DNA) of the five-membered ring. As a result, the furanose ring can adopt a variety of conformations which are represented by the pseudorotation cycle.(96) The presence of an electron-withdrawing group (EWG) at the 2′-position steers the conformational equilibrium of the furanose ring toward the RNA-like C3′-endo sugar pucker (Figure 8).(97-99) This orientation positions the 2′ and 4′-oxygen atoms in a favorable gauche conformation.
    In the absence of the 2′-EWG, the conformational equilibrium shifts toward the DNA-like C2′-endo sugar pucker where the 3′- and the 4′-oxygen atoms are in a favorable gauche conformation. This seesaw equilibrium changes the distance between the 3′- and 5′-phosphodiester moieties, which has a profound impact on the overall structure and stability of nucleic acid duplexes. As a general rule, RNA/RNA duplexes are more stable than DNA/DNA duplexes and RNA/DNA duplexes have intermediate stability. Medicinal chemists have used the above principle to design a very large number of sugar modified analogues which mimic the RNA-like C3′-endo sugar pucker as a general strategy to enhance the RNA-binding affinity of ASOs.(100, 101)

    5.2 2′-O-Me RNA (2′-OMe)

    2′-O-Me RNA (Figure 9) is a naturally occurring RNA analogue. It was one of the earliest sugar modifications employed in antisense medicinal chemistry and remains a widely used modification to improve the drug-like properties of certain classes of ASOs. Chimeric ASOs comprising of a central gap region of PS DNA flanked on either side with 2′-OMe were originally used for RNase H based antisense applications.(102, 103) 2′-OMe is widely used to improve the nuclease stability of siRNA. Introducing 2′-OMe at positions 2–3 in the guide strand reduces off-target effects but also appears to reduce potency. Uniformly modified 2′-OMe ASOs have been employed extensively to modulate RNA splicing.(104) Drisapersen, a uniformly PS modified 2′-OMe ASO designed to skip exon 51 was recently evaluated in the clinic for treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.(105) Unfortunately, the drug was not approved for lack of efficacy, highlighting that challenges still remain for translating observations from preclinical animal models to humans.

    5.3 2′-O-Methoxyethyl RNA (MOE)

    The MOE modification (Figure 9) represents one of the most widely used sugar modifications in antisense medicinal chemistry. Several MOE containing ASOs have entered clinical development in the past decade and one ASO, Kynamro, was recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of familial hypercholesterolemia.(106-108) MOE is widely used in the flanks of RNase H active ASOs(109) and to modulate splicing.(110-112) The larger size of this modification is not as well tolerated by Ago2, which makes close contacts with the RNA duplex in the minor groove.(113) However, MOE has been used to enhance stability of single- and double-stranded siRNA from exonuclease mediated metabolism.(114, 115)
    The methoxyethyl substituent in MOE represents an ethylene glycol moiety appended at the 2′-position of RNA.(116) The presence of a second oxygen atom within two carbon atoms of the 2′-oxygen atom of RNA imparts restricted rotation around the ethylene linker which positions the oxygen atoms in a gauche orientation relative to each other. Structural studies showed that the MOE side chain traps a molecule of water and increases the hydration and steric hindrance in the vicinity of the 3′-phosphodiester linkage. This results in a significantly improved nuclease resistance profile relative to 2′-OMe ASOs.(117) The restricted rotation of the MOE side chain further rigidifies the ribose C3′-endo sugar conformation and improves affinity for complementary RNA.

    5.4 2′-Fluoro RNA (FRNA)

    The 2′-fluoro modification of RNA (FRNA, Figure 9) replaces the 2′-OH group with a fluorine atom which is roughly the same size as a hydrogen atom but is highly electronegative.(118, 119) This modification has been extensively investigated in the context of oligonucleotide therapeutics and appears to have a privileged role for enhancing the drug-like properties of siRNA.(120) FRNA modified ASOs have also been used for modification of hammerhead ribozymes,(121) in the flanks of gapmer ASOs,(103) in the sense and antisense strands of siRNA duplexes,(120, 122) in ssRNAi,(114) in microRNA antagonist,(11, 123, 124) and to orchestrate the behavior of splice modulating ASOs.(125) Macugen is an oligonucleotide aptamer targeting vascular endothelial growth factor 1 (VEGF1), which is partially modified with FRNA and approved by the FDA for treatment of macular degeneration.(126)
    FRNA steers the conformation of the furanose ring toward the RNA-like C3′-endo sugar pucker, and modified oligonucleotides show improved duplex thermal stability when paired with RNA complements.(127, 128) Unlike the 2′-hydroxyl group in RNA which participates in extensive H-bonding with water molecules in the minor groove, the 2′-fluorine atom does not participate in interactions with water molecules. Instead, improved RNA affinity is ascribed to increased enthalpy as a result of stronger Watson–Crick base-pairing(129) and to polarization of the 2′-hydrogen atom in the furanose ring.(130)

    5.5 4′-Thio-Modified DNA and RNA

    Replacement of the 4′-oxygen atom in DNA and RNA with sulfur provides 4′-thio nucleic acids (Figure 9). The 4′-thio DNA analogue was modestly stabilizing and showed improved resistance to endonucleases but not 3′-exonucleases.(131) Imbach et al. showed that 4′-thio RNA oligonucleotides showed enhanced affinity for RNA and were significantly more resistant to cleavage by serum nucleases.(132, 133) Structural studies showed that 4′-thio RNA pairs with complementary RNA to form stable duplexes with standard A-form helical geometry.(134) 4′-Thio RNA thus represents a structurally similar yet nuclease-resistant analogue of RNA. 4′-Thio-RNA modified siRNA were shown to maintain(135) or slightly improve activity and stability.(136) 4′-Thio RNA also forms stable duplexes when paired with complementary 4′-thio RNA modified nucleic acids,(137) and this property was utilized to optimize the stability of an aptamer.(138)

    5.6 Locked Nucleic Acid (LNA) or 2′,4′-Methyleneoxy Bridged Nucleic Acid (BNA)

    2′-Modified nucleic acid analogues enhance binding affinity for RNA by steering the conformation of the furanose ring into the C3′-endo sugar pucker. The groups of Imanishi and Wengel independently explored the effect of locking the furanose ring into the C3′-endo sugar pucker by creating a covalent tether between the 2′- and the 4′-positions. This strategy led to the identification of locked nucleic acids (LNA) or 2′,4′-methyleneoxy bridged nucleic acids (BNA) which exhibit dramatic increases in RNA-binding affinity (+5 to +9 °C per incorporation) when incorporated into oligonucleotides and paired with complementary RNA or DNA (Figure 10).(139-142)
    Structural studies of LNA/LNA duplexes demonstrated that the helix was compressed and comprised of ∼14 base-pairs per helical turn (as opposed to 10 for B-form DNA and 11 for A-form RNA).(143) These observations suggested that the enhanced affinity obtained using LNA oligonucleotides was a result of improved base stacking. LNA modified oligonucleotides have been extensively evaluated in diagnostics and for therapeutic applications.(12, 144) LNA modified gapmer ASOs show increased potency in animals, but the modified designs also showed increased risk for causing hepatotoxicity which is dependent on ASO sequence and design.(145, 146)

    5.7 2′,4′-Constrained Ethyl BNA (cEt)

    The structural attributes of MOE and LNA nucleosides were combined to determine if this could mitigate the increased risk of hepatotoxcitiy observed with LNA ASOs.(147) Just as tethering the methyl group of 2′-O-Me RNA to the 4′-position of the furanose ring provides LNA, the 2′-O-methoxyethyl substituent in MOE can also be tethered to the 4′-position to provide 2′,4′-constrained MOE nucleosides. These analogues were termed R- or S-cMOE depending on the configuration of the substituent at the newly created chiral center (Figure 11). Both analogues showed LNA-like duplex stabilizing properties when incorporated into oligonucleotides and paired with complementary DNA and RNA. cMOE modified oligonucleotides also showed a greatly enhanced stability profile versus nuclease mediated degradation.(148)
    Structural studies showed that the 2′,4′-restraint enforces the C3′-endo sugar pucker in S-cMOE nucleosides.(149) However, the 2′-methoxyethyl side chain had a distinctly different orientation and hydration pattern in the S-cMOE modified duplex structure as compared to MOE-modified duplexes.(117) Further modeling studies suggested that the steric bulk of the 2′-substituent in cMOE nucleotides interferes with the metal binding pocket in the active site of the endonuclease and provided a rationale for the greatly improved nuclease resistance exhibited by these modifications.(149) In biological studies, replacing LNA in the flanks of gapmer ASOs with R- and S-cMOE mitigated the hepatotoxicity produced by the parent LNA gapmer ASO. However, these ASOs also showed significantly reduced activity in mice.
    To determine if the activity of cMOE gapmer ASOs could be improved while maintaining the beneficial effects on toxicity, the size of the substituent group was reduced to provide the 2′,4′-constrained 2′-O-ethyl (cEt) analogues. The R- and S-cEt nucleoside analogues (Figure 11) are also locked in the C3′-endo sugar pucker, and modified oligonucleotides displayed LNA-like enhancements in RNA binding affinity but a greatly improved resistance to nuclease mediated degradation. In mice, S-cEt modified gapmer ASOs showed LNA-like activity without producing hepatotoxicity.(147) The improved therapeutic profile of S-cEt gapmers led to this modification being selected at the next generation chemistry platform at Ionis Pharmaceuticals. S-cEt modified ASOs have shown increased potency in animal models and in human trials relative to MOE gapmer ASOs and an improved toxicity profile relative to LNA gapmers.(150-154)

    5.8 The Family of 2′,4′-Bridged Nucleic Acids

    Given the success of LNA and cEt modifications for enhancing ASO properties, a very large number of BNA modifications have been described in the literature (Figure 12). Replacing the 2′-oxygen atom in LNA with sulfur (2′-thio-LNA)(155, 156) is well tolerated, while replacing with a basic nitrogen leads to a slight reduction in duplex thermal stability (2′-amino-LNA).(157) The 2′-oxygen in LNA has also been replaced with selenium (SelNA), and modified oligonucleotides were found to be substrates for KOD and other polymerases.(158)
    As discussed above, introducing alkyl groups of varying size on the 2′,4′-bridge of LNA is well tolerated and the cEt and cMOE modifications display LNA-like affinity for complementary nucleic acids.(148, 149) Obika recently introduced the cyclopropyl BNA modification which is bis-substituted on the 2′,4′-bridge and also shows LNA-like binding affinity for RNA.(159) Interestingly, introducing methyl groups at the 5′-position of LNA has a configuration dependent effect on RNA affinity.(160) The S-5′-Me isomer shows LNA-like affinity, while the R-5′-Me isomer was less stabilizing. NMR studies on the nucleoside monomer suggested that the 5′-methyl group changes the rotational preference around the C4′–C5′ exocyclic bond which appears to impact affinity of the modified oligonucleotides for complementary RNA.
    Obika et al. reported the synthesis of the oxyamino BNA scaffold which shows LNA-like affinity for RNA.(161) Switching the connectivity of the oxyamino moiety provided aminooxy BNA which was less stabilizing. Interestingly, appending a methoxy group on amino-BNA restored RNA-binding affinity(162) while introducing a guanidine group (GuNA) enhanced affinity for DNA.(163) Obika has also synthesized a number of other BNA analogues which incorporate amide (AmNA),(164) sulfonamide (SuNA),(165) urea (UreaNA),(166) and oxyamido(167) linkages in the 2′,4′-bridge and shown that they enhance binding affinity for RNA.
    Nielsen prepared a series of analogues where the 2′-oxygen atom is replaced with carbon (cLNA) using a ring-closing metathesis approach.(168, 169) Most of these analogues showed slightly reduced binding affinity for RNA relative to LNA. Chattopadhyaya prepared a series of cLNA analogues using an elegant intramolecular radical cyclization reaction.(170) In general, replacing the 2′-oxygen atom in LNA with carbon which is less electronegative was found to be less effective for enhancing RNA-binding affinity. To determine if introducing an electron-withdrawing group adjacent to the 2′-carbon in cLNA analogues can provide LNA-like affinity, oligonucleotides modified with Fluoro cLNA(171) and the R- and S-Me cLNA(172, 173) were evaluated in thermal denaturation experiments. None of these analogues were able to show LNA-like affinity, suggesting that orientation of the electron withdrawing group could be important. Interestingly, the methylene cLNA analogue where the 2′-oxygen atom was replaced with an exocyclic methylene group showed LNA-like binding affinity for RNA and DNA complements. Structural studies suggested that the exocyclic methylene maintains a net electronegative potential at the brim of the minor groove and does not interfere with the water of hydration network.(173)
    The Obika group has also reported a number of additional analogues which have larger 2′,4′-bridging groups relative to LNA. The prototypical member of this series is ethylene bridged nucleic acid (ENA), which shows LNA like binding affinity for complementary nucleic acids (Figure 13).(174) Increasing the size of the tether (PrNA)(175) or introducing unsaturation (DpNA)(176) reduced affinity. Some of the loss in affinity could be recovered by introducing oxygen atoms (BNA COC(177) and ethyleneoxy BNA(178)) in the bridging group, suggesting that reducing hydrophobicity is beneficial. Lastly, a disulfide linked BNA has also been prepared and was shown to be responsive to redox stimuli.(179)

    5.9 Other Ring Expanded BNA Analogues

    The 2.2.1 ring system in LNA represents a conformational mimic of the C3′-endo sugar pucker.(180) Several researchers have examined the effect of replacing the 2.2.1-dioxabicyclo ring system with other bridged ring systems. ENA represents an example where the 2′-oxamethylene bridge in LNA was replaced with a 2′-oxaethylene bridge, resulting in the formation of a 3.2.1 ring system. ENA shows LNA-like affinity for complementary RNA(174) and does not appear to perturb the modified duplex.
    In contrast, insertion of a methylene group between the 3′-carbon and the 2′-oxygen atom results in the formation of cANA, which was found to be very destabilizing.(181) Conformational analysis suggested that the six-membered ring in c-ANA exists in a half-chair type conformation, which does not mimic the C3′-endo sugar pucker.(181) Similarly, LCeNA (locked cyclohexene nucleic acid), where the oxamethylene group in cANA was replaced by an unsaturated ethylene group, was also destabilizing.(182)
    Expansion of the 2.2.1 ring system in LNA to a 2.2.2 ring system as exemplified by boat-shaped glucopyranosyl nucleic acid (bsNA) was also unsuccessful.(183) The poor result observed with the 2.2.2 scaffold was rationalized by changes in the lean of the base and the glycosidic torsion angles which presumably interferes with duplex formation. Interestingly, an analogue which represents the 2.2.2 version of α-L-LNA was slightly more successful but still less stabilizing as compared to α-L-LNA (Figure 14).(184) Overall, ring expanded BNA analogues appear to not provide additional benefits and add to complexity of synthesis.

    5.10 α-L-LNA

    Wengel et al. identified α-L-LNA as a high affinity RNA recognition scaffold by evaluating oligonucleotides modified with all eight stereoisomers of LNA.(185, 186) α-L-LNA represents the alpha anomer of enantio-LNA (L-LNA), and oligonucleotides modified with this monomer form a seamless duplex with RNA. Unlike LNA, whose 2′,4′-oxamethylene bridge lies in the minor groove, the 2′,4′-oxamethylene bridge of α-L-LNA lies in the major groove of the modified duplex. α-L-LNA modified duplexes exhibited an intermediate character between A- and B-type helical geometries,(187) which led to some initial excitement that such duplexes could serve as substrates for RNase H.(188) The interesting properties of α-L-LNA also spurred the synthesis of several structural analogues such as α-L-amino-LNA for use in oligonucleotide-based diagnostic applications.(189) Replacing the 2′-oxygen atom in α-L-LNA with an exocyclic methylene group(173, 190) resulted in significant duplex destabilization, presumably as a result of a steric clash of the methylene group with the 3′-adjacent nucleotide.
    ASOs modified with other analogues of α-L-LNA such as R-6′-Me-α-L-LNA,(191) 3′-Me-α-L-LNA,(192)R-5′-Me-α-L-LNA, and its S-5′-Me isomer(193) have also been evaluated. With the exception of the S-5′-Me analogue, the other analogues displayed high affinity recognition of RNA. An α-L-LNA modified gapmer ASO targeting PTEN showed excellent potency for reducing gene expression in mouse liver without producing hepatotoxicity. However, this ASO showed a higher propensity to cause immune stimulation indicated by increased liver and spleen weights. Interestingly, this increase in organ weights could be mitigated by replacing α-L-LNA monomers with R-5′-α-L-Me-LNA but not 6′-Me or 3′-Me-α-L-LNA nucleotides. These observations highlight the ability of 5′-substituents to mitigate the immune stimulatory effects of some PS modified ASOs.(194)

    6 Six-Membered Ring Analogues

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The five-membered furanose ring in DNA or RNA can be replaced with six-membered ring systems which exist in the chair, half-chair, or boat cyclohexane conformations (Figure 15).(195) The six-membered ring in hexitol nucleic acids (HNA)(196) exists preferentially in the chair conformation with the nucleobase in an axial orientation. This chair conformation mimics the C3′-endo conformation of RNA and has one less 1,3-diaxial interaction as compared to the chair with the equatorial nucleobase. In contrast, the six-membered ring in cyclohexenyl nucleic acid (CeNA)(197) exists in a conformational equilibrium between two half-chair conformations which mimic the C2′- and C3′-endo sugar puckers of DNA and RNA, respectively. As a result, CeNA modified oligonucleotides show lower RNA-binding affinity as compared to the more rigid HNA analogues. The bicyclo[3.1.0] ring system in North-methanocarba (NMC)(198) nucleotides resembles the “boat” conformation of cyclohexane and is also an effective structural mimic of the C3′-endo sugar pucker.(199) The appended cyclopropyl ring rigidifies the conformation of the cyclopentane ring without the need of a 2′-electron withdrawing group.
    The RNA-binding affinity of HNA, CeNA, and NMC scaffolds can be enhanced by the incorporation of an electron withdrawing group such as hydroxyl or fluorine adjacent to the nucleobase. Interestingly, enhancement is only seen with analogues where the fluorine is installed in the “ribo” configuration (FHNA, F-CeNA, and F-NMC) as opposed to fluorine in the “ara” configuration, which is destabilizing. Crystal structures of FHNA and Ara-FHNA modified DNA duplexes showed that in FHNA, the axial fluorine atom juts out into the minor groove where it does not experience any unfavorable steric interactions.(200) In Ara-FHNA, geometrical constraint imposed by the six-membered ring positions the equatorial fluorine atom in close proximity to O4′ of the 3′-adjacent nucleotide, resulting in steric repulsion and partial unstacking of the nucleobases, thus causing duplex instability.

    7 Bicyclo and Tricyclo DNA

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The bicyclo/tricyclo DNA class of nucleic acid modifications introduced by Leumann (Figure 16)(201) represents one of the earliest examples of using conformational restraint to improve affinity for complementary RNA and DNA. In the bcDNA class, conformational mobility around torsion angles γ and δ is restricted by introducing a carbocyclic ring between the 3′- and the 5′-positions on the furanose ring.(202-204) However, bcDNA modified oligonucleotides do not enhance binding affinity toward complementary DNA or RNA, as the appended carbocyclic constraint shifts torsion angle γ in the ap range instead of the standard +sc range found in natural nucleic acid duplexes.(205)
    Several structural variations of the bcDNA scaffold were investigated to coax the 5′-hydroxyl group into a pseudoaxial orientation and move torsion angle γ back into the standard +sc range with little success.(206-212) Interestingly, recent studies showed that introducing fluorine at the 6′-position in bcDNA can enhance the RNA-binding affinity by formation of a pseudo H–F bond between the fluorine and the H5 on the pyrimidine nucleobase.(213) This interaction presumably facilitates Watson–Crick base-pairing by reducing flexibility around the glycosidic torsion angle χ.
    Improvement in RNA affinity can also be achieved using the tricycloDNA scaffold.(214) In this analogue, an additional cyclopropyl ring was appended onto the cyclopentane ring system of bcDNA. X-ray crystallography studies of tcDNA modified duplexes showed that the increase in RNA affinity likely results from a compensatory change in torsion angles α and β.(215) 2′-Fluorination of tcDNA improves affinity for RNA by enhancing the strength of Watson–Crick base-pairing.(216) The therapeutic potential of tcDNA oligonucleotides was exemplified by examining tcDNA gapmers in mice where they showed robust antisense effects for reducing the targeted mRNA in liver and extrahepatic tissues such as kidney, diaphragm, quadriceps, and heart.(217) Uniformly modified tcDNA ASOs have also shown excellent activity for splice correction in animal models of Duchene muscular dystrophy.(218) Interestingly, tcDNA modified oligonucleotides form spontaneous nanoparticles in aqueous solution which appear to enhance their cell-uptake properties.(219)

    8 Constrained Nucleic Acids (CNA)

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    α,β-CNA improves affinity for DNA and RNA complements by constraining torsions angles α and β in the oligonucleotide backbone in the canonical ranges observed in B-form DNA duplexes.(220, 221) Conformational restraint is exerted by tethering the nonbridging oxygen in the phosphodiester backbone to the 5′-position of the nucleoside, resulting in the formation of a dioxaphosphorinane ring system. Inversion of stereochemistry at the ring phosphorus atom or at the C5′ position provided epimeric analogues, which had a very destabilizing effect on duplex thermal stability.
    Incorporation of the epimeric α,β-CNA analogues into the gap region of RNaseH ASOs targeting SNPs linked to the CAG expansion in mutant huntingtin transcripts, showed differential ability to modulate allele selective silencing.(222) The α,β-D-CNA analogue (S configuration at C5′, Figure 17), in which α is constrained in the +sc range (as opposed to –sc in canonical B-form duplexes), was used to stabilize ssDNA hairpin structures because of its ability to induce a bend in the sugar–phosphate backbone.(223) In addition, α,β-D-CNA was also used as a chain terminator for proof reading DNA polymerases.(224)
    Synthesis of constrained nucleic acid analogues which restrict torsion angles α, β, and γ (α,β,γ–D-CNA) or δ, ε, and ξ (δ,ε,ξ-D-CNA) by tethering a C4′-hydroxymethyl substituent to the nonbridging oxygen in the phosphodiester backbone has also been reported.(225) In addition, syntheses of analogues which constrain torsion angles ε and ξ in addition to the endocyclic torsion angle νο (ε,ξ,νο-D-CNA) has been reported.(226) The conformational analysis of several members within the CNA family suggests that many of these analogues will not be useful to stabilize oligonucleotide duplexes with complementary RNA or DNA, and this may limit their utility for antisense applications.

    9 Dual Constrained Nucleic Acid Analogues

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Over the past two decades, at least three distinct strategies for restricting the conformation of natural nucleic acids to enhance RNA-binding affinity have been described.(227) The first strategy restricts rotation around torsion angles γ and δ in DNA, as exemplified by the tcDNA scaffold.(201) A second strategy improves affinity by restricting backbone torsion angles α and β into the canonical ap and −sc range observed in A-form DNA duplexes (α,β-CNA).(221) The third, and perhaps most successful, strategy involves locking the nucleoside furanose ring in the RNA-like C3′-endo sugar pucker, as exemplified by the family of 2′,4′-bridged nucleic acids.(228)
    While each of the above approaches have been explored individually, combining two or more strategies of conformational restriction into a single molecule could provide incremental increases in binding affinity. To explore this hypothesis, Hanessian et al. recently reported the class of dual constrained modifications, which restrict the sugar pucker in the C3′-endo conformation and also restrict γ in the +sc orientation (Figure 18).(227) One dual constrained analogue based on the α-L-LNA scaffold indeed showed enhanced RNA affinity, while a second analogue was slightly destabilizing relative to α-L-LNA (Figure 19).(229) In the β-D-LNA series, one dual constrained analogue showed LNA-like binding affinity for RNA while a second analogue was less stabilizing.(230) Examination of structural models suggested that the six-membered carbocyclic may experience tighter contact with the sugar–phosphate backbone in analogues which showed lower affinity in both series.(230)

    10 Design of Therapeutic Oligonucleotides

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The precise positioning of chemical modifications within a therapeutic oligonucleotide fundamentally determines which antisense mechanism the oligonucleotide can harness inside the cell (Figure 20). Oligonucleotides which harness the RNA degrading mechanisms such as RNaseH or siRNA typically have more precise design requirements as the modification pattern has to be compatible with the biochemistry of the enzyme.(32, 231) In contrast, oligonucleotides which function via occupancy-based mechanisms can be designed with greater flexibility and a broader set of building-block modifications. However, even with design constraints, the permutations generated by variation of oligonucleotide sequence and length, position, and type of modification, and other variables can be complex and bewildering.

    10.1 Design of RNaseH ASOs

    ASOs which contain >5 contiguous DNA nucleotides typically activate the RNase H pathway.(103) First-generation RNase H active ASOs were comprised of fully phosphorothioate modified DNA. These ASOs had enhanced metabolic stability and improved pharmacokinetic properties relative to full phosphodiester oligonucleotides but still had several limitations as a drug molecule. To address these limitations, second-generation designs were introduced which are chimeric ASOs with a central “gap” region of PS DNA nucleotides flanked on either end with other chemically modified nucleotides.(102, 103) This design is referred to as a “gapmer” and is currently the most extensively investigated ASO design in animals and humans.(232) The central gap region supports RNase H mediated cleavage of the targeted RNA, while the modified nucleotides in the flanks or “wings” improve ASO affinity, metabolic stability, and tolerability.
    Typical Gen 2.0 ASOs are chimeric oligonucleotides with a central gap region of 7–14 DNA nucleotides flanked on either end with 2–5 2′-modifications (Figure 9). The 2′-modifications in the flanks of gapmer ASOs can be replaced with tricyclo DNA (tcDNA),(217) hexitol nucleic acids (HNA),(200) or 2′,4′-bridged nucleic acids (BNA),(233) suggesting that a broad range of structural classes are tolerated. These modifications enhance affinity for RNA as compared to 2′-modifications, which permits the use of ASOs as short as 12- or 14-mers,(234) although a 16-mer length is more typical.(150, 153, 154) Longer ASOs with BNA modifications in the flanks have also been reported, but they typically show reduced activity compared to shorter BNA gapmer ASOs.(235, 236)
    Shorter ASOs with BNA-type modifications in the flanks enhance ASO potency in the liver and in extrahepatic tissues.(217, 234) Although the mechanistic rationale for the enhanced potency observed with shorter ASOs in animals is not well understood, it is not because of higher accumulation of drug in tissues(147) and could be a result of differential binding to intracellular proteins which presumably facilitate escape of ASOs trapped within endosomal compartments.(237)
    Replacing DNA within the gap-region of RNaseH ASOs with other chemical modifications is not employed routinely as most sugar modifications do not support RNase H activity in the vicinity of the site of incorporation.(32) Some recent studies showed that introducing chemical modifications in the gap region can modulate the allele selectivity of ASOs which target single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) for treatment of autosomal dominant disorders such as Huntington’s disease.(31, 222) The enhance allele selectivity results from modulating RNase H cleavage of matched and mismatched RNA via appropriate positioning of chemical modifications near the 5′-end of the gap region.

    10.2 Design of siRNA

    A number of chemical modifications have been investigated for improving the drug-like properties of double-stranded siRNA which function via the RISC pathway.(113, 238-240) The double-stranded nature of the siRNA enhances nuclease stability relative to single-stranded designs, which are heavily modified to enhance nuclease stability.(114) As a result, duplex siRNA are typically protected only at the 3′- and 5′-ends with phosphorothioate or other backbone modifications.(241) The internal regions of the oligonucleotide are most commonly protected using alternating designs of FRNA and 2′-OMe modifications,(122) although other modification patterns have also been employed.(136) Recent work has also highlighted the utility of a metabolically stable phosphate mimic (5′-vinyl phosphonate) for enhancing potency of chemically modified single- and double-stranded siRNA in animals.(115, 242, 243)

    10.3 Design of ASOs for Non-RNA Degrading Mechanisms

    ASOs which function via occupancy-based antisense mechanisms such as splice switching or translational arrest or which antagonize endogenous microRNAs have to be designed such that they do not activate RNA degrading mechanisms.(8, 244) These ASOs are typically designed with minimal RNA nucleotides and are often heavily modified with phosphorothioate linkages to improve metabolic stability and pharmacokinetic properties. These ASOs can be designed as a combination of PS DNA dinucleotides,(245) 2′-ribofuranose modifications,(124) and other affinity enhancing modifications such as 2′,4′-linked bridged nucleic acids (BNA)(246) or tricyclo DNA (tcDNA).(247) Use of high affinity modifications enabled the silencing of microRNA families in mice using seed-targeting LNA ASOs as short as 7- and 8-mers.(248) Alternatively, ASOs for non-RNA degrading mechanisms can also be designed using peptide nucleic acids or phosphorodiamidate linked morpholino oligonucleotides.(249, 250)

    11 Modulating Toxicological Properties of Oligonucleotides

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Toxicities for oligonucleotide therapeutics have been broadly classified in two categories.(251) One class of toxicities arise from interactions of ASOs with plasma and cellular proteins and are independent of hybridization to RNA.(252) Hybridization independent toxicities such as complement activation(253) and other pro-inflammatory toxicities(254) have progressively been mitigated through the evolution of chemical modifications and oligonucleotide design strategies.(255)
    A second class arises from unintended hybridization of the ASO to off-target RNA by Watson–Crick base-pairing. Hybridization-based toxicities can be managed by designing the oligonucleotide to bind mRNA sequences which are unique and by judicious screening to guard against unintended off-target downregulation. For RNaseH ASOs, the use of high affinity BNA modifications can increase the risk for hepatotoxicity,(145) which can be mitigated by small changes in sequence(146) or structure.(147, 256) Recent research has implicated certain sequence motifs,(257) genes with long introns,(258) very long pre-mRNA transcripts,(259) endosomal pathways,(151) and nonspecific protein binding(260) as potential mechanisms for toxicity. For siRNA, hybridization-based toxicities can be mitigated by using several strategies including asymmetric duplexes to bias strand loading,(261) by reducing affinity of the seed region(240) and other appropriate use of chemical modifications.(262)

    12 Modulating Pharmacokinetic Properties of Oligonucleotides

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Phosphodiester oligonucleotides (even with sugar modified regions) show poor protein binding properties and as a result are rapidly filtered into the urine and excreted.(14) Typical strategies to enhance their pharmacokinetic properties rely on the use of backbone modification or conjugation approaches to impart some protein binding characteristics or by encapsulating the oligonucleotide within nanoparticulate formulations. Recent advances in lipid nanoparticle (LNP) technology have enabled very effective delivery of oligonucleotides to the liver in rodents and in humans.(263) However, tolerability in the clinic still remains a concern and requires that the formulation be administered with maximally tolerated doses of steroids and antihistamines to suppress immune responses to the particles.(264, 265)

    12.1 Backbone Modifications

    The most commonly used chemical modification to enhance ASO pharmacokinetic properties in the PS linkage.(266) Sugar and backbone modifications can impart enhanced nuclease stability, but the ability to improve protein binding is a unique feature of PS oligonucleotides.(237, 267) This allows the oligonucleotide to bind plasma proteins and circulate transiently in the blood compartment before partitioning on to proteins in the tissue interstitium and on the cell surface.(268) Cellular internalization is thought to occur by endocytosis and macropinocytosis which delivers ASOs into endolysosomal compartments.(269-272) The mechanisms by which ASOs escape these compartments is not well understood, but depleting members of the endosomal sorting complex required for transport-I (ESCRT-I) enhanced ASO activity, suggesting that this complex is involved in the release of chemically modified ASOs from endolysosomal compartments.(273) Recently, stabilins 1 and 2 were shown to bind PS ASOs with high affinity and internalize them into cells and tissues in mice.(51) The stabilin class of scavenger receptors clears heparin and several negatively charged sulfated carbohydrate polymer components of the extracellular matrix from circulation,(274) suggesting a common pharmacophore with negatively charged PS ASOs.
    In contrast to negatively charged PS ASOs, phosphorodiamidate morpholino oligonucleotides (PMOs, Figure 7) are charge-neutral.(81) PMOs have poor protein binding properties which causes them to be rapidly eliminated from the body after systemic injection.(275) As a consequence, PMOs are administered at relatively high doses in the clinic (30–50 mg/kg, 2.1–3.5 g dose for a 70 kg human).(276) Activity of PMOs in animals can be enhanced by conjugation to polycationic peptides,(84) but safety concerns have prohibited their progress in the clinic.(277) The contrast between the cellular uptake properties of negatively charged PS ASOs and neutral PMOs underscores a common misconception that reducing charge can improve cellular uptake and pharmacokinetics of therapeutic oligonucleotides.(44)

    12.2 ASO Conjugates

    Conjugation of lipophilic groups which enhance hydrophobicity or other moieties which target ASOs to specific cell types has long being recognized as a strategy to enhance ASO activity in animals (Figure 21).(100) Early study with cholesterol conjugated PS ASOs showed that this moiety enhances ASO accumulation in the liver.(278) These observations were also reproduced using double-stranded siRNA(279) as well as single-stranded micro RNA antagonist ASOs(280) which showed enhanced activity in animals relative to their unconjugated counterparts. Recently, a tocopherol conjugated ASO heteroduplex has also shown enhanced activity in animal models.(281) The increased potency using lipid conjugates was attributed to enhanced hydrophobicity and association with serum lipoproteins which was thought to facilitate delivery of the polar ASO across the plasma membrane.(282)
    More recently, conjugation of trivalent N-acetyl galactosamine (GalNAc) to siRNA duplexes or single-stranded ASOs enhances potency 10–60-fold for inhibiting gene targets expressed in hepatocytes.(239, 283) The improved potency is a result of targeted delivery of the oligonucleotide to hepatocytes via the asialoglycoprotein receptor (ASGR).(284) This receptor is abundantly expressed almost exclusively on hepatocytes and clears glycoproteins(285) and desialylated platelets(286, 287) from circulation. Targeted delivery of oligonucleotide therapeutics to specific cell types and tissues remains an active area of investigation with great potential for further enhancing the drug-like properties of oligonucleotide therapeutics.

    13 Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The field of oligonucleotide medicinal chemistry continues to evolve on various fronts. The early days of antisense medicinal chemistry focused on identification of new backbone modifications to help enhance ASO metabolic stability and modulate pharmacokinetic properties. This work was done in parallel with efforts to identify 2′-modified furanose analogues which enhanced binding affinity for complementary RNA by steering the conformation of the furanose ring toward the C3′-endo sugar pucker. Further elaboration of this concept provided the BNA class of nucleic acid analogues which provided unprecedented increases in binding affinity for complementary RNA. More recently, identification of cell-targeting strategies which improve potency by targeted delivery to hepatocytes have been enormously successful and transforming. Identifying additional targeting strategies which can enhance ASO potency in tissues outside the liver will likely be the focus of future medical chemistry programs. In addition, chemical strategies which enhance ASO specificity will also occupy center stage to further enhance safety of antisense therapeutics. These endeavors will challenge medicinal chemists to gain deeper understanding of antisense biology and endosomal trafficking pathways and provide chemical solutions which further enhance the profile of therapeutic oligonucleotides for human therapy.

    References

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    This article references 287 other publications.

    1. 1
      Bennett, C. F.; Swayze, E. E. RNA Targeting Therapeutics: Molecular Mechanisms of Antisense Oligonucleotides as a Therapeutic Platform Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 2010, 50, 259– 293 DOI: 10.1146/annurev.pharmtox.010909.105654
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      RNA targeting therapeutics: molecular mechanisms of antisense oligonucleotides as a therapeutic platform
      Bennett, C. Frank; Swayze, Eric E.
      Annual Review of Pharmacology and Toxicology (2010), 50 (), 259-293CODEN: ARPTDI; ISSN:0362-1642. (Annual Reviews Inc.)
      A review. Dramatic advances in understanding of the roles RNA plays in normal health and disease have greatly expanded over the past 10 years and have made it clear that scientists are only beginning to comprehend the biol. of RNAs. It is likely that RNA will become an increasingly important target for therapeutic intervention; therefore, it is important to develop strategies for therapeutically modulating RNA function. Antisense oligonucleotides are perhaps the most direct therapeutic strategy to approach RNA. Antisense oligonucleotides are designed to bind to the target RNA by well-characterized Watson-Crick base pairing, and once bound to the target RNA, modulate its function through a variety of postbinding events. This review focuses on the mol. mechanisms by which antisense oligonucleotides can be designed to modulate RNA function in mammalian cells and how synthetic oligonucleotides behave in the body.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXisVelurs%253D&md5=f87801c4bb9b4a54d39615e2a0210660
    2. 2
      Sun, H.; Zhu, X.; Lu, P. Y.; Rosato, R. R.; Tan, W.; Zu, Y. Oligonucleotide Aptamers: New Tools for Targeted Cancer Therapy Mol. Ther.--Nucleic Acids 2014, 3, e182 DOI: 10.1038/mtna.2014.32
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Oligonucleotide Aptamers: New Tools for Targeted Cancer Therapy
      Sun, Hongguang; Zhu, Xun; Lu, Patrick Y.; Rosato, Roberto R.; Tan, Wen; Zu, Youli
      Molecular Therapy--Nucleic Acids (2014), 3 (8), e182CODEN: MTAOC5; ISSN:2162-2531. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Aptamers are a class of small nucleic acid ligands that are composed of RNA or single-stranded DNA oligonucleotides and have high specificity and affinity for their targets. Similar to antibodies, aptamers interact with their targets by recognizing a specific three-dimensional structure and are thus termed "chem. antibodies.". In contrast to protein antibodies, aptamers offer unique chem. and biol. characteristics based on their oligonucleotide properties. Hence, they are more suitable for the development of novel clin. applications. Aptamer technol. has been widely investigated in various biomedical fields for biomarker discovery, in vitro diagnosis, in vivo imaging, and targeted therapy. This review will discuss the potential applications of aptamer technol. as a new tool for targeted cancer therapy with emphasis on the development of aptamers that are able to specifically target cell surface biomarkers. Addnl., we will describe several approaches for the use of aptamers in targeted therapeutics, including aptamer-drug conjugation, aptamer-nanoparticle conjugation, aptamer-mediated targeted gene therapy, aptamer-mediated immunotherapy, and aptamer-mediated biotherapy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsFagtbvM&md5=5d34df6f80e12382c4e7503cb6b7e93a
    3. 3
      Krieg, A. M. Mechanisms and Applications of Immune Stimulatory CpG Oligodeoxynucleotides Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Gene Struct. Expression 1999, 1489, 107– 116 DOI: 10.1016/S0167-4781(99)00147-5
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Mechanisms and applications of immune stimulatory CpG oligodeoxynucleotides
      Krieg, A. M.
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Gene Structure and Expression (1999), 1489 (1), 107-116CODEN: BBGSD5; ISSN:0167-4781. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review with 75 refs. Immune stimulation has been widely recognized as an undesirable side effect of certain antisense oligodeoxynucleotides (ODN) which can interfere with their therapeutic application. It is now clear that these dose-dependent immune stimulatory effects primarily result from the presence of an unmethylated CpG dinucleotide in particular base contexts ('CpG motif'). The sequence-specific immune activation is not just an exptl. artifact, but is actually a highly evolved immune defense mechanism whose actual 'goal' is the detection of microbial nucleic acids. In contrast to vertebrate DNA, in which CpG dinucleotides are 'suppressed' and are highly methylated, microbial genomes do not generally feature CpG suppression or methylation [1]. Immune effector cells such as B cells, macrophages, dendritic cells, and natural killer cells appear to have evolved pattern recognition receptors (PRR) that by binding the microbe-restricted structure of CpG motifs, trigger protective immune responses. Although the specific immune activation appears to have a variety of potential therapeutic applications, it is generally undesirable in antisense ODN. Immune stimulation may be avoided in antisense oligos by the selection of CpG-free target sequences, by the use of ODN backbones that do not support immune stimulation, or by selective modifications of the cytosine in any CpG dinucleotides.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXns1Sltbk%253D&md5=ef106c93924e0573bb5c3c5a57e29d9c
    4. 4
      Kormann, M. S.; Hasenpusch, G.; Aneja, M. K.; Nica, G.; Flemmer, A. W.; Herber-Jonat, S.; Huppmann, M.; Mays, L. E.; Illenyi, M.; Schams, A.; Griese, M.; Bittmann, I.; Handgretinger, R.; Hartl, D.; Rosenecker, J.; Rudolph, C. Expression of Therapeutic Proteins After Delivery of Chemically Modified mRNA in Mice Nat. Biotechnol. 2011, 29, 154– 157 DOI: 10.1038/nbt.1733
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Expression of therapeutic proteins after delivery of chemically modified mRNA in mice
      Kormann, Michael S. D.; Hasenpusch, Guenther; Aneja, Manish K.; Nica, Gabriela; Flemmer, Andreas W.; Herber-Jonat, Susanne; Huppmann, Marceline; Mays, Lauren E.; Illenyi, Marta; Schams, Andrea; Griese, Matthias; Bittmann, Iris; Handgretinger, Rupert; Hartl, Dominik; Rosenecker, Joseph; Rudolph, Carsten
      Nature Biotechnology (2011), 29 (2), 154-157CODEN: NABIF9; ISSN:1087-0156. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Current viral vectors for gene therapy are assocd. with serious safety concerns, including leukemogenesis, and nonviral vectors are limited by low gene transfer efficiency. Here we investigate the therapeutic utility of chem. modified mRNA as an alternative to DNA-based gene therapy. A combination of nucleotide modifications abrogates mRNA interaction with Toll-like receptor (TLR)3, TLR7, TLR8 and retinoid-inducible gene I (RIG-I), resulting in low immunogenicity and higher stability in mice. A single i.m. injection of modified murine erythropoietin mRNA raises the av. hematocrit in mice from 51.5% to 64.2% after 28 days. In a mouse model of a lethal congenital lung disease caused by a lack of surfactant protein B (SP-B), twice weekly local application of an aerosol of modified SP-B mRNA to the lung restored 71% of the wild-type SP-B expression, and treated mice survived until the predetd. end of the study after 28 days.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjtVOitg%253D%253D&md5=a2cbe302338473c68860f016aa084ea2

      Lima, W. F.; Wu, H.; Crooke, S. T. Human RNases H Methods Enzymol. 2001, 341, 430– 440 DOI: 10.1016/S0076-6879(01)41168-2
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    6. 6
      Cerritelli, S. M.; Crouch, R. J. Ribonuclease H: The Enzymes in Eukaryotes FEBS J. 2009, 276, 1494– 1505 DOI: 10.1111/j.1742-4658.2009.06908.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Ribonuclease H: the enzymes in eukaryotes
      Cerritelli, Susana M.; Crouch, Robert J.
      FEBS Journal (2009), 276 (6), 1494-1505CODEN: FJEOAC; ISSN:1742-464X. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. RNase H isoforms cleave the RNA of RNA:DNA hybrids that form during replication and repair and which could lead to DNA instability if they were not processed. There are 2 main types of RNase H, and at least one of them is present in most organisms. Eukaryotic RNases H are larger and more complex than their prokaryotic counterparts. Eukaryotic RNase H1 has acquired a hybrid binding domain that confers processivity and affinity for the substrate, whereas eukaryotic RNase H2 is composed of 3 different proteins: the catalytic subunit (2A), similar to the monomeric prokaryotic RNase HII, and 2 other subunits (2B and 2C) that have no prokaryotic counterparts and as yet unknown functions, but that are necessary for catalysis. Here, the authors discuss some of the most recent findings on eukaryotic RNases H1 and H2, focusing on the structural data on complexes between human RNase H1 and RNA:DNA hybrids that had provided great detail of how the hybrid binding- and RNase H-domains recognize and cleave the RNA strand of the hybrid substrates. The authors also describe progress made in understanding the in vivo function of eukaryotic RNases H. Although prokaryotes and some single-cell eukaryotes do not require RNases H for viability, in higher eukaryotes RNases H are essential. Gene Rnaseh1-null mice arrest development around embryonic day 8.5 because RNase H1 is necessary during embryogenesis for mitochondrial DNA replication. Mutations in any of the 3 subunits of human RNase H2 cause Aicardi-Goutieres syndrome, a human neurol. disorder with devastating consequences.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXjsFWgtro%253D&md5=7d0d29817166b972ff93547c9e1c0101
    7. 7

      [Crossref], Google Scholar

      Kole, R.; Krainer, A. R.; Altman, S. RNA Therapeutics: Beyond RNA Interference and Antisense Oligonucleotides Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2012, 11, 125– 140 DOI: 10.1038/nrd3625
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      RNA therapeutics: beyond RNA interference and antisense oligonucleotides
      Kole, Ryszard; Krainer, Adrian R.; Altman, Sidney
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2012), 11 (2), 125-140CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Here, we discuss three RNA-based therapeutic technologies exploiting various oligonucleotides that bind to RNA by base pairing in a sequence-specific manner yet have different mechanisms of action and effects. RNA interference and antisense oligonucleotides downregulate gene expression by inducing enzyme-dependent degrdn. of targeted mRNA. Steric-blocking oligonucleotides block the access of cellular machinery to pre-mRNA and mRNA without degrading the RNA. Through this mechanism, steric-blocking oligonucleotides can redirect alternative splicing, repair defective RNA, restore protein prodn. or downregulate gene expression. Moreover, they can be extensively chem. modified to acquire more drug-like properties. The ability of RNA-blocking oligonucleotides to restore gene function makes them best suited for the treatment of genetic disorders. Pos. results from clin. trials for the treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy show that this technol. is close to achieving its clin. potential.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtVGqt7k%253D&md5=0db21d536154c3ccd62ba0db1334e3bb

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Therapeutic Silencing of MicroRNA-122 in Primates with Chronic Hepatitis C Virus Infection
      Lanford, Robert E.; Hildebrandt-Eriksen, Elisabeth S.; Petri, Andreas; Persson, Robert; Lindow, Morten; Munk, Martin E.; Kauppinen, Sakari; Orum, Henrik
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 327 (5962), 198-201CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      The liver-expressed microRNA-122 (miR-122) is essential for hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA accumulation in cultured liver cells, but its potential as a target for antiviral intervention has not been assessed. We found that treatment of chronically infected chimpanzees with a locked nucleic acid (LNA)-modified oligonucleotide (SPC3649) complementary to miR-122 leads to long-lasting suppression of HCV viremia, with no evidence of viral resistance or side effects in the treated animals. Furthermore, transcriptome and histol. analyses of liver biopsies demonstrated derepression of target mRNAs with miR-122 seed sites, down-regulation of interferon-regulated genes, and improvement of HCV-induced liver pathol. The prolonged virol. response to SPC3649 treatment without HCV rebound holds promise of a new antiviral therapy with a high barrier to resistance.

      14
      In vivo imaging of oligonucleotides with positron emission tomography
      Tavitian, Bertrand; Terrazzino, Salvatore; Kuhnast, Bertrand; Marzabal, Stephane; Stettler, Olivier; Dolle, Frederic; Deverre, Jean-Robert; Jobert, Antoinette; Hinnen, Francoise; Bendriem, Bernard; Crouzel, Christian; Di Giamberardino, Luigi
      Nature Medicine (New York) (1998), 4 (4), 467-471CODEN: NAMEFI; ISSN:1078-8956. (Nature America)
      A review, with 22 refs., is given on [19F]-labeled oligonucleotides for positron emission tomog. (PET) imaging in primates. Results of a comparative anal. of tissue pharmacokinetics and biodistribution of a test oligonucleotide bearing different chem. modifications are reported. A sensitive method for measuring radioactive oligonucleotide metabolites in plasma was developed. The radiolabeling procedure does not hinder the hybridization ability of the oligonucleotides, opening the way to the development of PET scanning methods aimed at imaging in vivo the specific hybridization of antisense oligonucleotides.

      15
      Antisense oligonucleotide pharmacokinetics and metabolism
      Geary, Richard S.
      Expert Opinion on Drug Metabolism & Toxicology (2009), 5 (4), 381-391CODEN: EODMAP; ISSN:1742-5255. (Informa Healthcare)
      A review. Background: The use of oligonucleotides as therapeutic agents has elicited a great deal of interest. Basic understanding and evaluation of the pharmacokinetic properties of oligonucleotides is foundational to their appropriate design and application. Objective: To review the primary pharmacokinetic properties that drive successful use and delivery of oligonucleotides. Methods: The primary data set available in the published literature for summarizing the pharmacokinetic properties of oligonucleotides exists for single strand phosphorothioate antisense oligonucleotides and their chimeric chem. modifications (second generation). Where possible, data from other classes of compds. are contrasted with this base class. Results/conclusion: Although there are several different classes of oligonucleotides being developed as therapeutic agents, their pharmacokinetic properties by class are primarily a function of their backbone chem. and the resulting chem. relationship to biol. stability and plasma protein binding properties.
